Key Arguments: The Bill is a moderate and measured effort to strengthen and enforce the social media misinformation and disinformation code.
The current regulatory approach is inadequate given the rise of misinformation and disinformation.
The Bill should include more transparency in content moderation decisions and mechanisms for user appeals.
Digital platforms should respect media freedom and maintain public repositories of government takedown requests.
The ACMA should have expanded powers to address foreign interference and serious harms beyond content-based issues.
Third-party researchers should have access to platform data for transparency and effective enforcement.
The Bill should include whistleblower protection schemes and require digital platforms to have an Australian corporate presence.
Main Themes: Transparency and accountability in content moderation
Involvement of third-party researchers and stakeholders
Whistleblower protection and corporate presence in Australia
Notable Quotes: The Bill is timely, given mis- and disinformation is on the rise and our current regulatory approach is inadequate.
The regulatory powers in the Bill do not represent a radical departure from previous approaches.
The draft Bill strikes a good balance between free speech and moderation of content.
The ACMA should actively monitor the threat landscape as malicious actors adapt their tactics to the new regulatory environment.
